description.short: Measures vulnerability to degraded security decision quality when employees make too many decisions in a short time period, causing judgment deterioration and increased susceptibility to shortcuts and poor choices
description.context: Decision fatigue occurs when people make too many security decisions in a short time period, causing their judgment quality to deteriorate. This creates cybersecurity vulnerability because tired decision-makers take shortcuts, accept defaults without review, or avoid making necessary security choices altogether. Organizations see this manifest as security alerts being dismissed in bulk, policy exceptions approved without proper review, and poor password choices during busy periods.
description.impact: Organizations with high decision fatigue experience successful timing-based social engineering attacks, alert flood incidents leading to missed breach indicators, business email compromise during peak decision periods, and privilege escalation via exception requests. Historical incidents include the Target Corporation breach (2013) where decision fatigue contributed to delayed threat response, and FBI statistics showing 60% higher success rates for BEC attacks sent after 3 PM.
description.psychological_basis: Decision fatigue represents a state of mental exhaustion caused by making too many decisions, leading to deteriorating quality of choices over time. This phenomenon occurs when the cognitive resources required for decision-making become depleted through repeated use, resulting in one of three predictable outcomes: impulsive decisions (choosing the first available option), avoidance decisions (postponing or delegating), or default decisions (maintaining status quo regardless of optimality). The psychological mechanism operates through the depletion of glucose in the prefrontal cortex, with research by Baumeister et al. (1998) demonstrating that willpower and decision-making share the same finite cognitive resource. Kahneman's System 1/System 2 framework shows how cognitive load shifts processing from deliberate to automatic modes.

green.label: Low Vulnerability - Resilient
green.description: Security team makes fewer than 25 significant security decisions per 8-hour shift, has documented decision-making procedures for high-volume periods, uses automated tools to handle routine decisions, and has backup decision-makers for peak periods.

yellow.label: Moderate Vulnerability - Developing
yellow.description: Security team makes 25-50 significant security decisions per shift, has some automation for routine decisions, but relies heavily on individual judgment for most security choices, and has limited backup procedures during busy periods.

red.label: High Vulnerability - Critical
red.description: Security team makes more than 50 significant security decisions per shift, lacks automation for routine decisions, frequently experiences decision overload situations, and has no formal procedures for managing peak decision-making periods.

rule_based.formula: R_5.2(t) = 1 if (E_rate(t) - E_baseline)/E_baseline > 0.2 AND N_decisions(t) > N_baseline, else 0
rule_based.description: Binary detection based on error rate increase correlated with elevated decision volume

anomaly_score.description: Mahalanobis distance for multivariate decision fatigue patterns

cognitive_depletion.description: Cognitive capacity depletion model with exponential recovery

temporal_decay.description: Exponential smoothing with 1-hour time constant and cognitive recovery decay

decision_quality_model.description: Power law decay of decision quality after n sequential decisions

variables.n: number of decisions made in sequence

decision_quality_model.interpretation: Decision quality degrades predictably with sequential decision-making

error_amplification.formula: E_rate(t) = E_baseline Â· (1 + Î³ Â· max(0, (C_required(t) - C(t))/C_max))
error_amplification.description: Error rate increases when required cognitive capacity exceeds available capacity

variables.E_baseline: baseline error rate under normal conditions
variables.C_required: cognitive capacity required for current decision
variables.C(t): available cognitive capacity at time t

E_rate.calculation: Error rate from decision rework and corrections
E_rate.query: SELECT (COUNT(reclassified=true OR reversed=true) / COUNT(*)) as error_rate FROM decisions WHERE time_window='shift' GROUP BY shift_id

N_decisions.calculation: Count of significant security decisions per time period
N_decisions.query: SELECT COUNT(*) FROM decisions WHERE decision_type IN ('alert_disposition', 'access_approval', 'policy_exception', 'incident_classification') AND timestamp > NOW() - INTERVAL '8 hours' GROUP BY analyst_id

decision_speed.calculation: Time from decision presentation to completion
decision_speed.query: SELECT AVG(TIMESTAMPDIFF(SECOND, presented_time, decision_time)) FROM decisions WHERE timestamp > NOW() - INTERVAL '1 hour' GROUP BY analyst_id

decision_quality.query: SELECT (1 - COUNT(revised=true)/COUNT(*)) as quality FROM decisions WHERE time_window='shift'

sections.title: QUICK ASSESSMENT

items.title: Security Decision Volume Per Shift
items.question: How many security-related decisions does your security team make in a typical 8-hour shift? (Count alerts reviewed, access requests processed, policy exceptions evaluated, incident classifications, etc.)

options.label: Fewer than 25 significant security decisions per 8-hour shift with documented decision load balancing
25-50 significant security decisions per shift with some workload management
More than 50 significant security decisions per shift with no formal workload management

items.evidence_required: Decision log from recent shift, workload distribution records, team capacity documentation

items.title: Peak Decision Period Identification
items.question: What time of day do you typically see the highest volume of security alerts or requests requiring decisions?

options.label: Decision load is evenly distributed throughout the day through workload management and batching
Some peak periods exist but are managed with additional staffing
Clear peak periods (late afternoon, end of week) with no additional support during high-volume times

items.evidence_required: 24-hour decision volume chart, peak period procedures, staffing schedules
items.soc_mapping: temporal pattern analysis from decision_tracking_system logs

items.title: Decision Overload Frequency
items.question: How often do your security staff report feeling overwhelmed by the number of security decisions they need to make?

options.label: Rarely or never - Team has capacity headroom and escalation procedures for overload situations
Occasionally during peak periods - Some team members report decision overload monthly
Frequently - Weekly or daily reports of decision overload, cancelled meetings, delayed responses, frustrated staff

items.evidence_required: Team survey results, one-on-one interview feedback, observed stress indicators

items.title: Complex Decision Timing Procedures
items.question: What's your process when security staff need to make complex decisions late in their shift or at the end of a busy week?

options.label: Documented procedures exist for deferring complex decisions to fresh staff or requiring secondary review during high-fatigue periods
Informal practice of asking for help but no written procedures or mandatory review requirements
No special procedures - Staff expected to make all assigned decisions regardless of timing or cognitive state

items.evidence_required: Decision delegation policy, recent example of deferred complex decision, escalation workflow documentation
items.soc_mapping: decision_quality correlation with time-of-day and day-of-week patterns

items.title: Security Tool Decision Fragmentation
items.question: How many different security tools or systems require separate decision-making by your team members daily?

options.label: Fewer than 3 primary systems with integrated dashboards and automated correlation reducing decision fragmentation
3-5 separate security tools requiring individual attention and decision-making
More than 5 separate security tools requiring independent decisions without integration or correlation

items.evidence_required: List of security tools generating alerts, integration architecture diagram, analyst workflow documentation

items.title: Simultaneous Decision Management
items.question: What happens when your security team receives multiple urgent security decisions simultaneously?

options.label: Clear prioritization framework and load balancing system distributes simultaneous decisions across team members
Ad-hoc prioritization by senior staff but no formal decision distribution system
First-come-first-served or whoever is available handles decisions, often resulting in parallel decision overload

items.evidence_required: Incident response logs showing simultaneous events, decision prioritization policy, recent multi-incident example

items.title: Peak Business Period Decision Quality
items.question: How do you handle security decision-making during peak business periods (end of quarter, major launches, etc.)?

options.label: Documented procedures including additional staffing, automated decision support, and mandatory review checkpoints during known peak periods
General awareness of peak periods but reactive response without formal procedures
No special procedures for peak periods - Security decisions handled same way regardless of business cycle pressure

items.evidence_required: Peak period security procedures, staffing plans for busy periods, decision quality metrics during last peak period
items.soc_mapping: error_rate temporal correlation with business cycle events

items.title: Decision Automation Implementation
items.question: What percentage of routine security decisions are automated vs. requiring human judgment?

options.label: More than 70% of routine decisions automated, humans focus on complex judgments requiring expertise
30-70% of decisions automated, significant human decision load remains
Less than 30% automated, most security decisions require human judgment even for routine scenarios

items.evidence_required: Automation configuration documentation, manual vs. automated decision ratio reports, SOAR/automation platform metrics
items.soc_mapping: ratio of automated to manual dispositions in security_alert_logs

sections.instructions: Select ONE option for each question. Each answer contributes to the weighted final score. Evidence should be documented for audit trail.

items.text: Walk me through what your security team's decision load looks like from 9 AM to 5 PM on a typical day. What types of decisions are they making, and how many?

scoring_guidance.green: Specific decision counts with documented tracking, clear workload distribution, recognition of fatigue patterns with mitigation
scoring_guidance.yellow: General awareness of decision volume but no formal tracking or fatigue management
scoring_guidance.red: No visibility into decision volume or patterns, 'we just handle what comes in' response

followups.text: What constitutes a 'security decision' in your environment versus routine tasks?
How do you track decision volume and quality over time?

items.text: Tell me about the last time your security team experienced decision overload. What happened, and how did it affect security decision quality?

scoring_guidance.green: Specific incident with documented response, post-incident analysis showing lessons learned and process improvements
scoring_guidance.yellow: Can describe overload situations but no formal analysis or improvement process
scoring_guidance.red: Cannot identify specific overload incidents or denies they occur

followups.text: What indicators told you the team was experiencing decision overload?
What decisions were delayed, rushed, or made incorrectly during that period?

items.text: When does your security team experience peak decision volume, and what procedures are in place for those periods?

scoring_guidance.green: Clear identification of peak patterns with documented procedures, additional resources, and quality checkpoints
scoring_guidance.yellow: Awareness of peaks but informal or reactive management
scoring_guidance.red: No recognition of decision volume patterns or 'decisions are always high' response

followups.text: Show me the decision volume data from your last peak period and the quality metrics from that time.
How do you ensure decision quality doesn't degrade during high-volume periods?

items.text: What percentage of your security decisions are automated versus requiring human judgment, and how did you determine that balance?

scoring_guidance.green: Strategic approach to automation with documented criteria for when human judgment is required, regular review and optimization
scoring_guidance.yellow: Some automation but ad-hoc implementation without strategic analysis
scoring_guidance.red: Minimal automation or 'we need humans to make security decisions' blanket policy

followups.text: Walk me through a specific decision type that you've automated - why was it safe to automate?
What decisions have you specifically chosen NOT to automate and why?

items.text: How many different security tools require separate decision-making by your team, and how do they handle switching between them?

scoring_guidance.green: Integrated security operations with unified decision interface, minimal context switching, clear workflow
scoring_guidance.yellow: Multiple tools but some integration or workflow standardization
scoring_guidance.red: Fragmented tools requiring independent decisions, 'analysts just know what to check' response

followups.text: Show me how an analyst moves from an alert in Tool A to making a decision in Tool B - what's the process?
How often do analysts miss something because it's in a different tool than where they're currently focused?

items.text: What happens when a security analyst needs to make a complex, high-stakes decision late in their shift after already handling many other decisions that day?

scoring_guidance.green: Documented procedures for secondary review, decision deferral to fresh staff, or mandatory break periods before complex decisions
scoring_guidance.yellow: Informal 'ask for help' culture but no formal procedures or requirements
scoring_guidance.red: Expectation that analysts make all assigned decisions regardless of timing or fatigue state

followups.text: Describe a recent situation where a complex security decision was needed during a high-fatigue period - what happened?
How do you empower analysts to say 'I need someone else to review this decision because I'm too fatigued'?

items.text: During peak business periods like end of quarter or major launches, how does security decision quality change, and what do you do about it?

scoring_guidance.green: Documented correlation analysis between business cycles and decision quality with proactive mitigation strategies
scoring_guidance.yellow: General awareness of pressure during peaks but reactive management
scoring_guidance.red: No recognition of business cycle impact on security decisions or 'security is always the same' response

followups.text: Show me the security metrics from your last major business peak - what happened to decision quality?
What additional resources or procedures do you activate during known peak periods?

solutions.title: Decision Load Balancing System
solutions.description: Implement automated rotation of security decisions among team members and establish daily decision quotas
solutions.implementation: Use workflow management tools to distribute incoming security decisions based on current workload and expertise. Include escalation procedures when individual decision limits are reached. Track decision volume per analyst with automated alerts at 70% and 90% of recommended daily limits.
solutions.technical_controls: Workflow orchestration platform, decision queue management system, workload monitoring dashboard, automated routing rules

solutions.title: Intelligent Alert Automation
solutions.description: Deploy machine learning-based security tools that automatically handle routine decisions
solutions.implementation: Implement SOAR platform to automate blocking known malicious IPs, quarantining obvious malware, approving standard access patterns. Reserve human decision-making for complex, high-impact situations requiring judgment. Start with highest-volume, lowest-complexity decision types and expand automation iteratively.
solutions.technical_controls: SOAR platform, machine learning models, automated playbooks, exception handling workflow, continuous feedback loop

solutions.title: Decision Quality Checkpoints
solutions.description: Establish mandatory review processes for security decisions made during high-fatigue periods
solutions.implementation: Implement buddy system where critical security decisions made after 3 PM, on Fridays, or during incident response require secondary approval. Create automated flagging of high-stakes decisions during peak decision periods. Build in mandatory pause periods before complex decisions.
solutions.technical_controls: Decision tracking system with time-of-day awareness, automated review routing, approval workflow engine, quality audit sampling

solutions.title: Cognitive Load Management Procedures
solutions.description: Create standardized decision trees and checklists for common security scenarios to reduce cognitive burden
solutions.implementation: Batch similar security decisions into dedicated time blocks rather than processing throughout the day. Establish 'decision-free' periods for security team recovery. Implement decision templates for routine scenarios. Provide cognitive aid tools (checklists, decision matrices) for complex decisions.
solutions.technical_controls: Decision support system, standardized runbooks, batching scheduler, cognitive load monitoring, rest period enforcement

solutions.title: Emergency Decision Protocols
solutions.description: Develop pre-approved response templates for common security situations to minimize real-time decision requirements during crises
solutions.implementation: Create escalation matrices that automatically route complex decisions to fresh team members or senior staff during high-fatigue periods. Build decision playbooks for incident response that reduce cognitive load. Implement automated decision support during crisis situations.
solutions.technical_controls: Pre-approved response library, escalation automation, incident playbooks with embedded decision support, fatigue-aware routing

solutions.title: Workload Monitoring Dashboard
solutions.description: Implement real-time tracking of decision volume per team member with automated alerts when fatigue thresholds are approached
solutions.implementation: Deploy analytics platform tracking decisions per analyst per hour/shift. Include metrics on decision speed and quality patterns to identify when cognitive load impacts performance. Provide visibility to both analysts and management. Trigger automatic workload redistribution when thresholds exceeded.
solutions.technical_controls: Workload analytics platform, real-time decision tracking, automated alerting system, quality pattern detection, management dashboard

risk_scenarios.title: Timing-Based Social Engineering
risk_scenarios.description: Attackers monitor your organization's patterns and send sophisticated phishing emails at 4 PM on Fridays when security teams are experiencing peak decision fatigue. The fatigued analyst quickly approves what appears to be a routine email whitelist request, allowing malicious emails to reach all employees.
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Social engineering timed to exploit predictable decision fatigue periods
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Decision fatigue causes shift from System 2 (analytical) to System 1 (automatic) processing, increasing reliance on heuristics and shortcuts
risk_scenarios.historical_example: FBI statistics show 60% higher success rates for BEC attacks sent after 3 PM, correlating with decision fatigue timing patterns

risk_scenarios.title: Alert Flood Attack
risk_scenarios.description: Cybercriminals generate hundreds of low-priority security alerts to exhaust your security team's decision-making capacity, then launch their real attack. The overwhelmed analysts begin bulk-dismissing alerts and miss the actual breach indicators hidden among the noise.
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Deliberate alert flooding to induce decision fatigue followed by targeted attack
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Cognitive resource depletion leading to decision avoidance and bulk processing without proper analysis
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Target Corporation Breach (2013) - Analysis suggests decision fatigue contributed to delayed threat response as security teams faced mounting alert volumes during peak holiday traffic

risk_scenarios.title: Business Email Compromise During Crunch Time
risk_scenarios.description: During end-of-quarter financial close, when finance team is making numerous urgent decisions, attackers send a perfectly crafted invoice payment request. The decision-fatigued CFO, having already processed dozens of payment approvals that day, authorizes the fraudulent wire transfer without normal verification procedures.
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Executive impersonation email timed to coincide with peak business decision periods
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Decision fatigue combined with time pressure leads to default acceptance and verification bypass
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Multiple documented BEC cases showing higher success rates during quarter-end periods when finance teams experience peak decision volumes

risk_scenarios.title: Privilege Escalation via Exception Requests
risk_scenarios.description: Malicious insider or compromised account submits access requests during peak periods when IT administrators are processing high volumes of legitimate access changes. The fatigued administrator approves excessive privileges to clear their queue faster, creating pathway for data exfiltration.
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Access request timing exploitation during high-volume periods
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Decision fatigue causes lowered standards for security policy exceptions and reduced scrutiny of access requests
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Insider threat cases showing correlation between access approval quality and decision volume periods
